Bob Goodlatte [chairman of the committee] presiding.</hearing-info> <hearing-info paraId="2" speaker="">Present: Representatives Goodlatte, Smith, Chabot, Issa, Gohmert, Marino, Collins, Buck, Handel, Nadler, Lofgren, Johnson of Georgia, Jeffries, Cicilline, Lieu, Jayapal, and Demings.</hearing-info> <overview>Subcommittee on Courts, Intellectual Property, and the</overview> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="">Staff Present: Shelley Husband, Staff director; Branden Ritchie, Deputy Staff Director; Zach Somers, Parliamentarian and General Counsel; and Joe Keeley, Chief Counsel, the Copyright Alternative in Small-Claims Enforcement Act of 2017.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="">I will begin by recognizing myself for an opening statement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="">Like all creators, copyright owners, large and small, deserve to be compensated for their efforts. Thanks to the growth of the Internet economy, a creator now has the ability to distribute their works worldwide. However, this also means that those who view intellectual property as something worth stealing, also have a means to more easily distribute stolen works.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="">Small businesses make up the majority of American businesses, many of which are family-owned. They could be farmers, restaurants, dry cleaners, or any number of other professions. Just like larger businesses, they face issues that need judicial resolution, such as nonpayment, breach of contract, and other issues that directly impact their bottom lines.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="">Fortunately, a robust State court system exists to address business disputes. Larger companies and small businesses use a variety of measures to reduce the chances of theft and nonpayment, only turning to the courts when necessary. Litigation in America is expensive, and is not for the faint of heart. There are even State small claims courts for smaller value claims.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="">However, for most intellectual property disputes, only the Federal court system can hear legal disputes, and there is no equivalent small claims process.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="">This has led to one category of American creators frequently being on the losing end of intellectual property theft, small intellectual property creators.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="">Visual artists have identified the lack of such a small- claims process as a major detriment to their ability to hold those who infringe their works accountable.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="">During the last Congress, there were two separate bills to create a small-claims system for low-value copyright claims.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="">I am pleased that Congressman Jeffries has led the way this year on combined legislation, and that he and his staff have worked tirelessly with interested parties to incorporate a number of major changes to the legislation in order to improve its effectiveness and limit the ability of bad actors to abuse it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="">Earlier this year, the ranking member and I spoke about the importance of this issue for small creators. And I am glad to see that our colleagues have made so much progress.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="">Today's hearing will highlight all of this hard work and identify any potential remaining areas of concern.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="">The committee's goal, which I know is shared by Congressman Jeffries, is to implement an effective process for resolving small-value copyright claims.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="">Just like owners of physical property, American creators deserve a remedy when their intellectual property is used without the appropriate compensation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker=""> It is now my pleasure to recognize the ranking member of the committee, the gentleman from New York, Mr. Nadler, for his opening statement. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Nadler</speaker> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Mr. Chairman, 5 years ago, you spearheaded a comprehensive bipartisan review of the copyright system that consisted of careful, thoughtful analysis of various provisions of the Copyright Code, as well as how the copyright system is working for creators and users alike.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Nadler">At the culmination of that review, a few areas of consensus emerged, one of which was the need to reform the music licensing system.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Nadler">With legislation to address that issue unanimously sent off to the President this week, we can move on to the next issue calling out for action, namely the need to establish a small claims court to resolve small dollar infringement claims.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Nadler">A fundamental principle of law is that there is no right without a remedy. But unfortunately, many copyright holders today, particularly many visual artists lack sufficient remedies to protect their rights.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Nadler">This is because the cost of pursuing infringement claim in Federal court, particularly for small creators, is far greater, as much as 10 times or more, than the expected damages they would receive in a successful suit, making it virtually impossible to protect their works.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Nadler">While the damages at stake in these infringement claims may be small in terms of sheer dollar amount, even a few thousand dollars in uncollected royalties would represent a huge loss of income for someone like a photographer making just $35,000 or $40,000 a year. And few attorneys will take a case when such limited damages are at stake, because they would likely not recoup their costs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Even if the creator did successfully obtain judgment in his or her favor, the total cost of litigation would likely dwarf the damages awarded, making it a Pyrrhic victory, at best.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Nadler">The CASE Act seeks to address this important problem.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Nadler">This bipartisan legislation introduced by our colleague, Representative Hakeem Jeffries, would establish a claims court within the Copyright Office to hear a copyright suit seeking $30,000 or less in total damages.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Nadler">As envisioned by the CASE Act, this quote will be less expensive and much easier to navigate, even without an attorney, than Federal court. Based in large part on recommendations from the Copyright Office which conducted an exhaustive study of this issue, the bill would provide an affordable means for small creators to vindicate their rights.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Although a small claims court would provide a more conducive forum for small creators to file suit, the court's limited jurisdiction based on the bill's fairly nominal damage limit, as well as the reduced cost that would be incurred in defending against an infringement claim, or in seeking a declaratory judgment that use of a copyrighted work constitutes fair use, should make it an appealing venue for copyright users as well.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Nadler">If, however, a defendant would prefer not to submit to the jurisdiction of the small claims court, the bill allows such defendant to opt out.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Nadler">In recognition of certain concerns that are expressed by some stakeholders, Representative Jeffries worked tirelessly to refine this legislation, and as a result, now includes a number of revisions suggested by these stakeholders, including the organizations represented by two of our witnesses today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Nadler">These revisions include very heightened due process protections and provisions intended to reduce potential abuse of the system.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Nevertheless, some stakeholders still have certain concerns about the bill. That is why I am pleased to be holding this hearing today, so that we can better understand these concerns, and, hopefully, find solutions that may be acceptable to all stakeholders.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Nadler">I am a proud cosponsor of this legislation, and I thank Mr. Jeffries for his outstanding leadership on this issue.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Nadler">I also want to recognize the efforts of Representative Judy Chu, who introduced similar legislation in the last Congress, as well as the other cosponsors of this bill.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Nadler">I look forward to hearing from our witnesses, and I hope that today's hearing will help us lay the foundation for further action on this important legislation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Nadler"> I yield back the balance of my time. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Goodlatte</speaker> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Thank you, Mr. Nadler.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">It is now my pleasure to recognize the ranking member of the Subcommittee on Courts, the Internet and Intellectual Property, the gentleman from Georgia, Mr. Johnson, and ask that perhaps he could, at the conclusion of his remarks, yield to the chief sponsor of the legislation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte"> Mr. Johnson of Georgia. I would be happy to do so. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Goodlatte</speaker> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">The gentleman is recognized.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Mr. Johnson of Georgia. Thank you, Mr. Chairman. This hearing gives us an opportunity to examine the Copyright Alternative and Small-Claims Enforcement Act, also known as the CASE Act, which would provide copyright owners with an alternative to the expensive process of bringing infringement claims in Federal court.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">The CASE Act is supported by all types of the creators, including photographers, illustrators, songwriters, and authors.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Currently, Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over copyright claims. Federal litigation is expensive, and many small creators cannot afford to enforce their rights.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">The Copyright Office provided a detailed report on this issue, and I thank them for their hard work, which has helped us work towards a legislative solution.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Many of their recommendations are included in this bill. I am happy that stakeholders have been in negotiations about ways to further improve the bill. The most recent discussion draft of the bill includes many changes that attempt to address stakeholder concerns.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">While I am aware that there are still remaining concerns about the bill, I hope we can use this hearing as a way to continue to work together on the issue.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">I want to thank Congressman Hakeem Jeffries, Congressman Tom Marino, Congressman Doug Collins, and Congresswoman Judy Chu, as well as Congressman Ted Lieu for their work in putting together what this bill is as it is introduced today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte"> I would now like to yield the balance of my time to the author of this important legislation, Congressman Hakeem Jeffries. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Jeffries</speaker> <paragraph paraId="50" speaker="Mr. Jeffries">Well, thank you, Congressman Johnson, for yielding. I thank the chairman, Mr. Goodlatte, as well as Ranking Member Jerry Nadler, and my lead Republican sponsor, Congressman Marino, as well as all of my colleagues who have worked hard on this legislation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="51" speaker="Mr. Jeffries">Today, we are considering H.R. 3945, otherwise known as the CASE Act, which would create a fair and balanced forum for small creators to be able to vindicate their copyright under law.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="52" speaker="Mr. Jeffries">Copyright infringement is not a victimless crime. Photographers, illustrators, visual artists, writers, individual songwriters, musicians, all rely upon their creative works in order to put food on the table and support their families. But with every infringement, they lose an opportunity to do so.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="53" speaker="Mr. Jeffries">Unfortunately, under the current system, these creators are given a right without an adequate remedy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="54" speaker="Mr. Jeffries">As reported in the Copyright Office report from 2013, many copyright owners are independent creators who have very small infringement claims, but these creators do not have the means to vindicate their rights and protect their works from infringement in an Article III Federal court system.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="55" speaker="Mr. Jeffries">Survey conducted by the American Intellectual Property Lawyers Association reveal that the median cost to pursue a copyright infringement lawsuit, with damages less than $1 million, is approximately $350,000. The CASE Act would contemplate providing a remedy for people whose infringement claims do not exceed $30,000.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="56" speaker="Mr. Jeffries">Between the burden of attorney and court fees and the delay experienced, small creative artists and others who rely upon their copyright works as their bread and butter, are left without any vehicle or enforcement remedy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="57" speaker="Mr. Jeffries">The CASE Act will help fill this void by establishing a voluntary alternative form for small copyright owners that will enable them to enforce and protect their content in a fair, timely and affordable manner, and would also afford respondents the ability to do the same.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="58" speaker="Mr. Jeffries">The forum will be headed up by a new entity called the Copyright Claims Board, the CCB, housed within the Copyright Office. It is designed to allow both pro se rights holders as well as pro se respondents to obtain a fair proceeding.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="59" speaker="Mr. Jeffries">With the simplified process, this does not require the personal appearance of either parties, the board proceeding would not only be advantageous for the rights holder, but also would advantage pro se respondents as well, as but would not be saddled with similarly high costs of District Court litigation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="60" speaker="Mr. Jeffries">Because either party can easily opt out, the CCB satisfies the Article III and due process requirements of the Constitution and many safeguards have been built in to ensure that it will be fair and balanced, and above all else, it is consistent with our Article I, Section 8, Clause 8 responsibility to make sure that we promote the progress of science and useful arts in this context, allowing creators to be able to vindicate their rights under law.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="61" speaker="Mr. Jeffries"> I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Goodlatte</speaker> <paragraph paraId="62" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">We welcome our distinguished witnesses. And if you would all please rise, I will begin by swearing you in.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="63" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Please raise your right hand.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="64" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte"> Do you, and each of you, solemnly swear that the testimony you about to give, shall be the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth, so help you God? </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Goodlatte</speaker> <paragraph paraId="65" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Thank you. Let the record show that each of the witnesses answered in the affirmative.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="66" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Our first witness is Mr. David Trust. Mr. Trust is the Chief Executive Officer of the Professional Photographers of America.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="67" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Our second witness is Mr. Matthew Schruers. Mr. Schruers is the Vice President for Law and Policy at the Computer and Communications Industry Association.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="68" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Our third witness is Ms. Jenna Close. Ms. Close is the Director of Photography at Buck the Cubicle.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="69" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Our fourth witness is Mr. Jonathan Berroya. Mr. Berroya is the Senior Vice President and General Counsel for the Internet Association.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="70" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">And our final witness is Mr. Keith Kupferschmid. Mr. Kupferschmid is the Chief Executive Officer of the Copyright Alliance.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="71" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Thank you. I look forward to hearing from all of you today. Your written statement will be entered into the record in its entirety, and we ask that you summarize your testimony in 5 minutes. To help you stay within that time, there is a timing light on the table. When the light switches from green to yellow, you have 1 minute to conclude your testimony. When the light turns red, that is it. Time is up. And finish your remarks. Thank you very much.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="72" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Mr. Trust, you may begin.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="73" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">TESTIMONIES OF DAVID TRUST, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, PROFESSIONAL PHOTOGRAPHERS OF AMERICA; MATTHEW SCHRUERS, VICE PRESIDENT, LAW AND POLICY, COMPUTER AND COMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRY ASSOCIATION (CCIA); JENNA CLOSE, DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY, BUCK THE CUBICLE; JONATHAN BERROYA, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT AND GENERAL COUNSEL, INTERNET ASSOCIATION; AND KEITH KUPFERSCHMID,</paragraph>
Hearing.Statement: <opening>TESTIMONY OF DAVID TRUST</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="TESTIMONY OF DAVID TRUST"> CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, COPYRIGHT ALLIANCE </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Trust</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Trust">Thank you, Mr. Chairman. And Chairman Goodlatte, Ranking Member Nadler, and members of the committee, it is a pleasure to be here with you today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Trust">I have been asked to speak on behalf of Professional Photographers of America. We represent about 50,000 professional photographers, but in this particular instance, I have been also asked to speak on behalf of hundreds and hundreds of thousands of other small creators, including graphic designers and illustrators and other photographic groups that have joined together as a coalition of visual artists. Together, they make up the majority of America's copyright communities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Trust">It is true that in terms of sheer number of creators, copyright is much more small business than it is large. And that is healthy. Our country's creative diversity is a good thing; it is good for the economy; it is good for our society. And fostering abroad and diverse range of creators is the very foundation of copyright law.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Trust">But the diversity is only of value if we are able to protect all of those creators. The harsh reality of copyright in America is that it works for some creators, less for others, and not at all for the majority.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Trust">The problem is in the remedy for copyright. As it stands now, small creators who have seen their work used without permission, or just outright stolen, have had one path for relief, filing a lawsuit in U.S. Federal court. Of course, the reality is that path is no path at all.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Trust">Nobody is going to sue in Federal court over an infringement that averages well under $3,000. The math simply works against most creators.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Trust">And let's remember, it doesn't have to be big money to make a big difference. A $500- or $1,200 infringement can be the difference in paying the mortgage, or healthcare, or food on the table for the first family vacation in 5 years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Trust">The truth is, visual artists have, for decades, felt disenfranchised by America's copyright system, and for good reason. Where there is no remedy, there is no protection.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Trust">Now, we realize that this is an unintended consequence based on the evolution of copyright, and in particular, technology.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Trust">Nobody made a decision to leave out small creators, but with the CASE Act, we can make a decision to include them under the same umbrella of protections afforded other creators.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Trust">If this supersonic, evolving-by-the-second, hyper- competitive business environment we all live in teaches us anything, it is that we will pay attention to the needs of small businesses or we will lose them. And let me rush to point out that being a real professional photography has little to do with the camera and everything to do with the years of training. The camera is perhaps the least of their tools.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Trust">I can purchase a really nice drafting table. It doesn't make me an architect. Small creators dedicate years, decades, even generations, honing a craft that enriches our lives.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Trust">And here is a significant side note. Listen to this. Less than 5 percent of professional photographers regularly register their work with the Copyright Office. Is it because they don't value their work? Quite the contrary.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Trust">Research indicates that copyright and protecting their work is one of the issues that keeps them awake at night. They don't register because there is no viable remedy, which means 95 percent of possibly the largest class of copyright holder in America never pays a dime into the copyright system.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Trust">Our system disenfranchises the majority of its consuming universe. Small claims is the start to turning that around.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Trust">Are there concerns by others? I guess so, but it is hard to understand why. We are Americans. We believe in the protection of law.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Trust">If you make and sell furniture for a living, we protect you from theft. If you make and sell electronics, cars, or clothing, and sell those on Amazon or Etsy or eBay, we protect you from theft. If you make and sell tacos from a truck around the corner from the Rayburn Building, we protect you from theft.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Trust">Why, then, would we not create a remedy, a small claims process to protect hundreds of thousands of small creators who beautify and enrich and add color to our lives.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Trust">Oh, and by the way, if someone doesn't like the idea of participating in small claims, it is no problem. It is optional, just opt out.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Trust">We depend on these creators, we need these creators. Let's remember that when the Constitution what was drafted to include copyright, there were no motion pictures or software or networks. And don't get me wrong, we stand with all creators and all creators deserve protection. But at the time of the drafting of the Constitution, the copyright superstars were the authors and illustrators and artists and composers and songwriters, followed 60 years later by the first multimedia creators, professional photographers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Trust">Chairman Goodlatte and members of the committee, we all see the work of these small creators almost from the moment we open our eyes in the morning until we close them again at the end of the day.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Trust">For decades, generations, these small creators have been unprotected and underrepresented by our copyright system. We are at a crossroads. I truly believe that we will stand with our small creators or we will watch them disappear one by one, and with them, the color and the life that they bring to our world.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Trust">America's copyright system should be a beacon on the hill for the rest of the world, and creating a small claims remedy through the CASE Act puts us into position to become just that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Trust"> You are very gracious. Thank you so much for your time. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Goodlatte</speaker>

<opening>TESTIMONY OF MATT SCHRUERS</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="TESTIMONY OF MATT SCHRUERS"> Thank you, Mr. Trust. Mr. Schruers, welcome. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Schruers</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Schruers">Thank you. Chairman Goodlatte, Ranking Member Nadler, members of the committee. My name is Matt Schruers. I'm the VP for Law and Policy at CCIA, which represents Internet technology and communications firms.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Schruers">Thank you for the opportunity to discuss this claims proposal today. CCIA has a significant interest in properly scoped copyright remedies. Our members play a critical role in the existing creative landscape providing services, tools, and platforms that enable and facilitate users' ingenuity expression and creativity worldwide.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Schruers">These technologies afford the instantaneous and often free- to-the-user access, providing opportunities to reach out and engage with audiences around the world in ways not possible without the Internet.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Schruers">A new remedy for copyright plaintiffs should be considered in the context of the existing remedies available. That copyrights already robust remedies could be underserving plaintiffs is somewhat difficult to reconcile with the current wave of Federal copyright litigation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Schruers">2018 research found that serial litigants filing shotgun style, multiparty Doe claims frequently on pornographic works accounted for nearly half of all U.S. copyright litigation from 2014 to 2016. That is thousands of lawsuits against hundreds of thousands of potential defendants, many wrongfully accused.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Schruers">But let me be clear, that we recognize troll plaintiffs are not the plaintiffs about whom we are concerned today.
